Problem Overview

Problem 4.1 examines Order of Operations with positive and negative numbers. Students began their work with Order of Operations in the grade 6 unit Number Connections. This problem gives students an opportunity to understand the role of parentheses in clarifying the intended sequences of operations to carry out. Students deal with more complicated addition and subtraction computation strings and see why rules for computational order are necessary.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Review and expand understanding of the Commutative, Identity, Inverse, and Distributive Properties with the evaluation of rational number expressions.

Expand understanding of the impact of order of operation with rational number expressions with multiple operations.

NWDYK

Describe how the properties of rational numbers and the conventions of order of operations help you write and evaluate an expression?

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Start by reviewing the Order of Operations for whole numbers.

Suggested Questions:

  • Use parentheses and the + and - signs and the four numbers in the given order to write an equality. 5, 11, 9, 7 = 27
  • What other numbers can you obtain by using ( ), +, and - with these four numbers?

Presenting the Challenge

Hold a discussion of the conventions for the Order of Operations and the computations given.

Talk a bit about the use of parentheses with your students. Make sure that they understand parentheses as a grouping symbol. This means that you need to compute what is in the parentheses first. It also means that, when you write expressions to match word problems, you can insert parentheses to make sure that the expressions you write reflect the order of operations that you intend. For example, for the expression 5 + (-2) x (-3), you get 11 if you follow the Order of Operations. However, suppose you want the expression to mean adding first and then multiplying. You can insert parentheses to override doing multiplication before addition. Then (5 + (-2)) x (-3) = -9 because you compute the expression in parentheses first.

Also remind students that when you need grouping symbols such as parentheses inside parentheses, you can use brackets to make it easier to read. So, (5 + (-2)) becomes [5 + (-2)].

Have students work in groups of 3-4 to play the Dealing Up game in the Initial Challenge and then work on the What If...? Situations. Pass out the set of cards from Learning Aid 4.1A: Dealing Up Cards and one scoresheet using Learning Aid 4.1B: Scoresheet for Dealing Up to each group.
